item.title: Sources
item.description:
Fully put the idea onto paper
Look through given sources
Find external sources
Outline and 2 sources due11 Feb 2025
Finish Judith Butler
Find artistic inspiration in-progress- due17 Feb 2025
Storyline due17 Feb 2025
First Version Thesis in-progress- due25 Feb 2025
Upload as Website due27 Feb 2025
Character Sheet in-progress- due28 Feb 2025
Style Tests due28 Feb 2025
Symbols and Moodboard due28 Feb 2025
Storyboard due12 Mar 2025
Color Script due13 Mar 2025
Animatic due14 Mar 2025
References for All Movements due26 Mar 2025
Rough Animation due30 Apr 2025
Color Animation due15 May 2025
Final Touches due30 May 2025


Judith Butler
How Social Media Shapes Our Identity
Rubiks Kubus
Virtual Avatars


Camille (short animation)
Serial Experiments Lain (anime)
Ghost in The Shell (anime movie)
Claude Cahun, Marcel Moore (photography)
VIAL - LOUDMOUTH (music)
Who's Lila? (video game)

By this implementation:
Stuff highlighted like this actually falls into the timeline of the work itself.
During their childhood, they'd start showing subtle signs of this condition - a scar on their elbow looking like a ball joint connection, a lowering in body temperature maybe.
By the time that they're living on their own, it has progressed to be their entire left arm. They keep this as hidden as they can.
They find another person and connect with them enough for them to show them that they've been fully transformed by the condition. Maybe some kind of "Do you find this repulsive?" interaction.
I want to show them laying in bed, looking at their hand in a dim light, lost in thought.
They get up, walk into their bathroom, which is in a deteriorated state. At this point they're wondering who or what they are, and what will happen in the future. They remember how happy that person was - contrasted to how miserable their own visage in the mirror is. The visage in the mirror is out of sync.
They pick up a photo of themselves as a child. Happy, clueless, showing no sign of anything being wrong. It's hard to believe that person grew into what they are now.
The past version of themselves should not be a part of this - however, it still is. Frozen in time, the photos acting like a chain between the past and the present. The idea of the past self restricts the current self and taints its own existence. ->How Social Media Shapes Our Identity
They try to ignore it, but they're falling out with everyone around them.
One day, after passively existing around, they decide to look into it. They hop onto the internet, under a new name. They explore a completely new side to themselves - this forms a disconnect between the body and the mind.
After a while, the condition expands to their left shoulder. They're left wondering who they really are, again. They try to go to the mirror, to face themselves. The image is unclear, and even harder to recognize as themselves. Visual of a their reflection in the mirror shattering, each shard a different side of themselves. The old self, the new self, the doll parts, the internet persona.
They start hyperventilating, and the screen fades to the Visual of Mindspace as a room
Each of the identities has a different style, to show the different perspectives of the pieces of the MC's full identity. They are not one thing or the other.
Each of them can see things that the others can't

Similar to Heartbound's room.

This room gradually gets objects taken out of it, replaced, or added as you go through the game. They represent aspects of Lore (the MC). As such, this room is a visual representation of his mind.
Similarly, in Serial Experiments Lain, Lain's room is a representation of her changing sense of self, of her identity. The more intertwined she becomes with The Wired, the more computer parts emerge.


Pile of self-portraits as visual depictions of the idea of identity -> How Social Media Shapes Our Identity

I want to highlight the Abjectification of trans people with visual elements such as books or posters portraying the "puppeted" as dangerous.

I am all of these aspects of myself, maybe separately but at the same time. Accepting myself as I am, with my changing perspectives, is how I can see that I'm not incomplete.


Dankwoord
What constitutes an identity?
A Stranger to Myself
What is gender, really?
Identities in our digital world
Avatars - which self is truer?
What inspired me:
Conclusion


Initial identity crisis (original self vs "puppeted" self)
Hanging out with person
Find out that the person also has the condition
Confrontation with the person avoided
"Is it ok for me to be this way?"
Log online, separate identity ("persona")
Sleepless, "which one's the real me?"
Mirror scene
Room scene
Phone call with the person

item.title: Abjectification
item.description:
Casting someone off and separating them from norms and rules, 'other'-ing them.
Making them unworthy of sympathy.
Explored in Post-Structuralism as that which inherently disturbs conventional identity and cultural concepts.

item.title: Anti-Gender Movement
item.description:
The definition of the "Gender Ideology" that they fight against is inherently nebulous.
Gender is seen as something inherently unnatural and opposed to the "natural" order of things, such as "traditional family values" and whatnot.
Gender ideologues are characterized as powerful and demanding people's obedience, enforcing their own agenda, but also sneaky, capturing institution after institution behind the scenes. An inherent, impossible to prove threat.
In other words, the anti-gender movement seeks to abjectify the "gender ideologues".
The main point they're making is that "Gender Ideology" is against... whatever you think it should be, which is a very effective strategy. It doesn't really matter what it's a threat to, only that it's something that everyone can personally care about.
Though Jews are almost never mentioned in attacks on "gender ideology", genderists, and especially sexual minorities, are consistently Judaised in anti-gender discourse, that is, described in a language strongly reminiscent of conspiratorial antisemitism. The link becomes most obvious when Soros and Butler are mentioned, or when the term "Cultural Marxism," notorious for its antisemitic subtext, is employed...
Like Jews in antisemitic attacks, sexual minorities are presented as engaged in a secretive plot: they are scheming, devious and powerful. To this end, the term "homosexual lobby" is often used, and the link between homosexuality and cosmopolitanism or rootlessness is persistently made.
Furthermore, LGBT activists are routinely accused of sacrilege, their very presence is said to contaminate sacred events and spaces, while the rainbow flag is seen as offensive to religious sensibilities and patriotic feelings. Finally, like Jews in pre-World War II Eastern Europe, gays are blamed for provoking violent attacks by making themselves too conspicuous.
Agnieszka Graff and Elzbieta Korolczuk, Anti-Gender Politics in the Populist Moment
They are engaged in a Phantasm.
But what is the purpose of said Phantasm? What conclusion are they fearing?
We're dealing with a lot of systemic issues that people aren't equipped to criticize.
Under the system of Capitalism, women really are devalued, children really do live in an increasingly dangerous world, and there really are institutions that will trample on every value and tradition in order to make money.
People see the bad results of [capitalism], but they're invested in the system, and so the solutions become unthinkable.
The anti-gender movement is so effective in attracting mass support because it is structured and legitimised as a conservative response to the excesses of neoliberalism...
Agnieszka Graff and Elzbieta Korolczuk, Anti-Gender Politics in the Populist Moment
They want to paint the problems as a moral failure, rather than systemic.

item.title: Body Without Organs
item.description:
Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari propose a theory of identity where the self
is composed of a series of desiring-machines. Thus, rather than being one
simple entity, the self is a multiplicity of desires. The desiring-machines are
constantly involved in producing and reproducing various aspects of
identity. This composes an organism which Deleuze and Guattari refer to
as the “body without organs” (BwO). They refer to the BwO as an egg of
pure potential
If we picture the BwO as the center of a system, it itself is stable, nonproductive, and imageless. The desiring-machines which create the self surround the BwO and are constantly producing identities, images, personalities, etc.
The subject isn't at the center, but at the periphery

-> Just like how being Transgender is a state of becoming.
-> Judith Butler and Performative Gender
The desiring-machines seek to approach the limit in their different angles, but never quite reach it.
This challenges the assumption that online identities are necessarily false by asserting that all identities are fluid and multiple. The fact that online identities and avatar representations are more obviously fluid is actually a sign that they are closer to the reality of human identity than an offline identity defined by stability.
I am not the first to make the connection between the BwO and avatars. Christine Liao described her subjects’ avatars as BwOs when she studied the habits of Second Life fashion bloggers.
[Margrit Shildrick] argues that the BwO was never intended to be incorporeal, but simply to reject any (even temporary) stable identity that would give the subject an end to becoming. --> Identity Instability

item.title: How Social Media Shapes Our Identity
item.description:
Taken from this article.


In the past, adults refused to acknowledge children's agency, or imposed on them an idealized notion of innocence and purity. -> "Surely my child can't be [autistic|trans|queer]..."
Childhood as something to look back to, rather than experience.
Important: Screen Memories
[Social] media can prevent those who wish to break with their past from doing so cleanly. ... People who transition, for instance, often rely on having a clean break, visually, with their previous appearances; ... When [the Internet] was just "texts and clip art," it presented itself as a safe place [for transgender youth] -> Disconnect between Mind-Identity and Body
Inability to Escape the Past
Moratorium
What are the ramifications when an entire generation never gets the chance to experiment freely or to remake themselves?
Forgetting - that once taken-for-granted resource that all humans possessed - is now being pitted against the interests of technology companies. - Eichhorn
... retaining our sense of self across chasms that might destroy it
Selfies/portraits as a visual depiction of the idea of me
Photos embalm their subjects, encasing them in a "stilling sadness that kills what it attempts to save out of a fear of losing it"
most difficult memories aren't captured by photos, videos, or tweets
item.link: Research/How Social Media Shapes Our Identity.html
item.guid: Research/How Social Media Shapes Our Identity.md

item.title: Performativity
item.description:
Taken from this video.


'F' is a femboy. They stream themself playing games while looking fem and wearing fem clothing attributes.
But this category of content is deeply shaped by trends and stylized practices that one person cannot control.
To be a femboy is to put on attributes according to those societally determined trends, and to perform and act in a certain way.
It's less something that you are, and more something that you do
You have to learn these behaviors and subtle pointers.
Gender is something we do through repeated stylized acts. Not a property, but an embodied event.
read also: Shelley Budgeon, "Identity as an Embodied Event", in Body & Society
The ideas of coming out, or being true to yourself, imply the existence of a previous, authentic self that was hidden. Butler challenges that notion.

It's not that I exist and then I choose to perform gender in ways that you will recognize; I can't even form a concept of 'I' without using gendered language and stylized practices whose meaning exists prior to me.
Gender is one of the ways that human subjects come into existence.
Gender creates an illusion of a private self that exists before all of that, but this is just an illusion. "If a tree falls in a forest and nobody is there to hear it, it has no pronouns."

"Gender as performance" implies that people are innately genderless, and then put on costumes to present as a gender they want, but this is not what Butler is saying.
"Performative" -> "Technical philosophy term for when you say something, and by saying it, you also do it."
(ex. "I promise...", "I sentence you...")
This is not to say that anyone can be whatever they want to say they are.
Our very concept of ourselves as gendered subjects requires a social world. We depend on others for the recognition we need to become gendered subjects.

There is no volitional subject behind the mime who decides, as it were, which gender it will be today. On the contrary, the very possibility of becoming a viable subject requires that a certain gender mime be already underway.
Judith Butler, "Performative Acts and Gender Constitution: An Essay in Phenomenology and Feminist Theory," in Theatre Journal



The idea that sex and gender are different is erroneous, in that it assumes the existence of an innate quality based on genitals, genes or gametes or even something psychological.
For millenia, male-dominated societies exploited women, and justified it by claiming that we are naturally inferior. [...] Misogyny has consistently justified itself by appealing to 'facts' about our bodies that are simply made up
read also: Eleanor Janega, The Once and Future Sex
One is not born, but rather becomes a woman.
Simone de Beauvoir, The Second Sex
(Abigail): [...] one is born female, but 'woman' is a socially constructed ideal of subordination, that we are encouraged to embrace and punished for defying.
Include: Monique Wittig
According to Butler, we should question the idea that sex is a natural category. We also used to think race was a natural category. "They wrote scientific papers about it and measured people's skulls and took blood samples..."
Again, Butler isn't saying that physical differences aren't real.
They're just saying that whatever facts there might be about "biological sex", we can only learn them, and talk about them through gender.
We can't really think about sex, gender or race separately. All 3 exist as social constructs and categories of people, and signifiers of their expected position within the system.
"Physical features" appear to be in some sense there on the far side of language, unmarked by a social system. It is unclear, however, that these features, could be named in a way that would not reproduce the reductive operation of the categories of sex.
In other words, "sex" imposes an artificial unity on an otherwise discontinuous set of attributes. As both discursive and perceptual, "sex" denotes an historically contingent epistemic regime, a language that forms perception by forcibly shaping the interrelationships through which physical bodies are perceived.
Judith Butler, Gender Trouble


People are pushing for a strict definition of a woman based on biology to "protect" women.
But what matters here aren't the facts about the victim, but the actor's intentions and assumptions.
If someone stabs someone because they see them walking next to a gay bar and assume they're gay, that's a hate crime based on sexuality even if the person isn't actually gay.
The attributes of the victim should never be considered the cause of a crime or mistreatment done against them. This is the "But what was she wearing?" pitfall.
According to both Butler and De Beauvoir, defining womanhood is and has always been a key strategy of the patriarchy.
Trying to set an exact definition is always going to be an exclusionary project.
Any category [...] imposes limits.


We can only see our bodies through the lens of symbolism.
So while the penis is only a lump of flesh and cells, it signifies power, strength, domination, and the threat of male violence.
The International Court of Human Rights recognizes it's probably morally wrong to make a certain group of people undergo expensive, difficult, potentially risky, invasive medical procedures that they may not want in order to do things like get married.
We naturalized the "bundle of cultural and symbolic meanings" of sex, classifying all those born with a specific organ as male and without it as female.
This is, in other words, another social, cultural construct that doesn't account for gender identity or even intersex people.
The policy of sending trans women to male prisons makes prison worse for a certain section of the population because of the way that they are born.
This is justified by the perceived threat, not based on any facts about the person, not based on the crime they committed, but only based on what genitalia they have.

The danger that these prisoners are said to pose is unlike any dangers that might be substantiated in a court of law and redressed through punishment... Establishing dangerousness is not the same as establishing guilt... A certain level of dangerousness takes a human outside the bounds of law, and even outside the bounds of the military tribunal itself, makes that human into the state's possession, infinitely detainable.
What counts as "dangerous" is what is deemed dangerous by the state, so that, once again, the state posits what's dangerous, and in so positing it, establishes the conditions for its own preemption and usurpation of the law... If a person is deemed dangerous, then it is no longer a matter of deciding whether criminal acts occurred.
Indeed, "deeming" someone dangerous is an unsubstantiated judgement that in these cases works to preempt determinations for which evidence is required. Judith Butler, Precarious Life
--> Performative Speech
Not Subjectification, but Abjectification
When the powers that be say a certain group of people are inherently dangerous, [...] that's them trying to use performative speech to make that group of people impossible to listen to. We become not subjects, but abjects. A problem to be managed against our will, in the name of a public good that does not recognize us as part of the public.


Abigail does a great job at humanizing the trans experience, and makes it easy to empathize whether you're trans or not.

item.title: Monique Wittig
item.description:
This sex and gender distinction is just another layer of control.
-> Monique Wittig, One is Not Born A Woman
Simone [de Beauvoir] thinks that 'woman' is an oppressive social construct, but 'female' somehow isn't?

By admitting that there is a "natural" division between women and men, we naturalise history... Not only do we naturalise history, but also consequently we naturalise the social phenomena which express our oppression, making change impossible... Lesbian is the only concept I know of which is beyond the categories of sex (woman and man), because the designated subject (lesbian) is not a woman, either economically, or politically, or ideologically. For what makes a woman is a specific social relation to a man, a relation that we have previously called servitude, a relation which implies personal and physical obligation as well as economic obligation ("forced residence", domestic corvée, conjugal duties, unlimited production of children, etc.), a relation which lesbians escape by refusing to become or to stay heterosexual. Monique Wittig, One is Not Born A Woman
-> Rubiks Kubus, TODO: LGBTQIA+ and capitalism

item.title: Moratorium
item.description: Erik Erikson A period of trial and error that society allows adolescents, who are permitted to take risks without fear of consequence, in hopes that doing so will clarify a "core self - a personal sense of what gives life meaning."

item.title: Phantasm
item.description:
Technical Philosophy Term
A particular way of misinterpreting the world by projecting your feelings onto it.
People use Phantasms to avoid Cognitive Dissonance in the face of Anxiety.
An exercise in not making sense and not thinking, because thinking would make you reach conclusions that you're afraid of.
Anyone that challenges your Phantasm is "committing an act of aggression" towards your protective measures.

item.title: Rubiks Kubus
item.description:
Taken from this article.


ik ook best op mannen kan vallen, ooit, misschien -> sexuality is a spectrum and labels shouldn't be completely strict. Many people's identities are scrutinized and questioned based on other people's arbitrary definitions of who they can or can't be. (TODO: Labels as communication)
-> The author also explains, in other words, that although she may have been attracted to a guy, she most definitely can't have a relationship with a man.
This is described as a utilitarian behavior, a "zelfbeschermings-mechanisme"
Important: Our heteronormative society is set up so that men have sexual and emotional - therefore economic - access to women. The existence of lesbians makes men fear that their access isn't unconditional or enforced, but instead it can only happen on women's terms. The beneficiaries of such a system hate the idea that the victimized class could be put on equal ground. Adrienne Rich in Signs, Vol. 5, No. 4, Women: Sex and Sexuality, 1980, p. 643

"In een kapitalistische samenleving heeft degene die iets wil verkopen toegang tot de potentiele consument via de behoeften en verlangens vandie consument. Het is dus logisch dat in een samenleving die daarnaast ook nog eens heteronormatief is,dehomoin eerste instantie buiten boord valt. Je homoseksualiteit ontkennen of afzwakken betekend zodoende: jezelf niet buiten de maatschappij plaatsen." -> TODO: LGBTQIA+ and capitalism
"Op een bepaalde manier is homoseksualiteit gemakkelijker te exploiteren dan heteroseksualiteit." Queer people are grouped entirely based on their identity or sexuality. Most people don't see that there's more to the person than just that they're trans or gay or otherwise queer. "Don't make it your whole personality" mentality -> TODO: Tendency to Minimalize Others
"gebrekkige representatie die inherent is aan de feit dat de term 'homo' wordt gebruikt om een enorme groep verschillende mensen onder een noemer te vatten." -> Not matching the definition perfectly, as it's represented, as a stereotype, makes people feel invalid, or makes people see others as not valid. TODO: Labels as communication
"Het domein van homoseksualiteit strekt zich uit tot ver buiten haar eigenlijke grenzen" - being queer overshadows everything else you are to many people. If you're trans, that is suddenly relevant to know no matter the context, because it means you're "different". TODO: Tendency to Minimalize Others
People often conflate being a lesbian with a genital preference; namely, rejecting penises. This can refer both to dildos and as a way to exclude trans lesbians from lesbian spaces. This sort of purism is always used to exclude others.

item.title: Screen Memories
item.description:
Sigmund Freud
Brains choose which memories to keep, to focus on, and in what sort of light to see them.
This is often used to obscure painful experiences -> TODO: Traumatic Amnesia

item.title: Keypoints
item.description:
Taken from this study.



text-based RPG experiences (MUDs – multi-user dungeons) in the 90s, and described these early types of virtual worlds as laboratories for experimenting with identity building
When people adopt an online persona they cross a boundary into highly-charged territory. Some feel an uncomfortable sense of fragmentation, some a sense of relief. Some sense the possibilities for self-discovery, even self-transformation” (Turkle 1997, p. 260).
“I’m not one thing, I’m many things. Each part gets to be more fully expressed in MUDs than in the real world. So even though I play more than one self on MUDs, I feel more like ‘myself’ when I’m MUDding” --> Multiplicity
The authors conclude that players are more interested in transforming their bodies than their personalities in virtual worlds. This conclusion supports the idea that users are constructing an authentic ideal self, since they cannot become attached to an avatar who acts vastly different from themselves. --> (Cacioli and Mussap 2014, p. 157)


--> Serial Experiments Lain

denied any division between the digital world and the physical world. Because of this, he argued that instead of viewing digital content only through the lens of content analysis, researchers should use any of the methods they would use if their subjects were available in a physical location.


The majority of participants, however, expressed an identification with their avatars to various degrees.
Thus, it was not only the physical appearance of the avatar that helped James experience an ideal embodiment, but also his story and interactions with other players.
--> The of the avatar came first, then James adopted it for himself.
Female characters are given less customization and are often made in the image of what a woman "should" be like, as opposed to how male characters are allowed to the freedom of choice.
Trans women gamers were most interested in simply being able to exist as women in the virtual world. Given that trans women are much more likely to be physically attacked than trans men are, this makes sense.
Experiencing things through an avatar can alleviate dysphoria. Additionally, the way people interact changes based on the gender of the avatar.
First, the longer it has been since a person has made their trans identity public and began progress on any medical transition goals, the less likely they were to consciously experiment with gender in video games. Several mentioned being obsessed with every detail of their avatar’s physical appearance before they came out or in the first few years after.
All participants had other avatars as well. --> All contribute to the sense of self.

item.description:
Exported Obsidian files are in the bar to the left.
The main project file is Incomplete.
